entries.name: Not of this World
entries: You are from a different world, with little knowledge of how this world operates.

action.name: Multiattack

action.name: Scimitar
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 4}, reach 5 ft. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) Slashing damage, plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) Slashing damage if the attack roll had {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 4}, range 80/320 ft. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) Piercing damage, plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) Piercing damage if the attack roll had {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}.

bonus.name: Nimble Escape
entries: Gurk takes the Disengage or Hide action.

reaction.name: Redirect Attack
entries: {@actTrigger} A creature Gurk can see makes an attack roll against it. {@actResponse} Gurk chooses a Small or Medium ally within 5 feet of itself. Gurk and that ally swap places, and the ally becomes the target of the attack instead.

deity.name: Ikaris
deity.title: the Ember-Spear
deity.symbol: Burning spear plunged into a spiral of ash
deity.worshipers: Raiders, mercenaries, pyromancers, cultists of destruction

entries: Ikaris was born in the last breath of a dying god, birthed from the scream of a city razed not for conquest, but spite. He is the god of fires that cannot be extinguished, of cities leveled without purpose, of armies that kill for no cause but fury. Unlike gods of flame who bring warmth or rebirth, Ikaris is fire's spiteful scream — uncontrolled, mindless, and starving.

He is depicted as a charred warrior wrapped in ever-burning bandages, his face a skull of cracked obsidian, his voice the roar of collapsing towers. His followers do not conquer; they burn and salt the earth. His apocalyptic sermons scorch stone and are spoken by tongues blackened to ash.

entries.name: Proverb
entries: In his wake, not even memory survives.

deity.name: Velkhar
deity.title: the Unmaking Tongue
deity.symbol: A blackened tongue curled around a shattered crown
deity.worshipers: Spies, assassins, schemers, betrayers, secretive cults

entries: Where truth once shaped the divine order, Velkhar slithered in shadows, whispering truths so twisted they turned allies into executioners. He is the god of beautiful lies and slow poison, of promises broken not in rage, but in cold calculation. His touch does not scorch — it erodes, unravels, hollows out.

Velkhar appears as a serene, androgynous figure cloaked in chains of silk and thorns, with a mouth sewn shut but always whispering in the minds of those who doubt. He thrives in court intrigue, holy schisms, and the slow collapse of faith. Velkhar demands no violence; he inspires it through corrupted trust and unravelled meaning.

entries.name: Proverb
entries: Velkhar does not kill — he makes others want to.

deity.name: Cirelda
deity.title: the Giver of Seasons
deity.symbol: A sprouting seed beneath a rising sun

entries: Cirelda appears most often as a halfling woman, hands dirt-stained, with vines growing through her hair and cracked earth at her feet. Her body may shift subtly with the seasons - green in spring, golden in summer, russet in autumn, pale in winter.

She governs the slow miracle of the natural world — sowing, growth, decay, and renewal. Her worship is quiet, yet essential: grain scattered on fresh soil, a whispered prayer before a child is born, a wreath placed on fresh-turned earth.
She is not an ancient god of war or prophecy. She emerged wherever people waited on the land, watched the skies, and hoped for something to grow.

entries.name: Proverb
entries: The seed remembers the sun, even in the dark.

deity.name: Matrien
deity.title: the Hearth-Keeper
deity.symbol: A flame cradled between two hands

entries: Matrien is often shown as a broad-shouldered goliath, draped in patchwork robes or woolen shawls, their skin textured like hearthstone or warm clay.
They watch over the home, the shared table, and the quiet vigil. Where one holds the door for a stranger, or a neighbor mends another's roof, Matrien is present.

They are not revered with pageantry, but through humble practice: in the breaking of bread, in the tending of fires, in the defense of the small against the uncaring. They are invoked during childbirth, first snowfalls, and final farewells.
Some claim Matrien is as old as memory. Others believe they are born fresh in every place that chooses kindness over cruelty.

entries.name: Proverb
entries: What is shared is never truly lost.

deity.name: Velmarra
deity.title: Lady of the Ledger and Loom
deity.symbol: A sheaf of grain bound in green ribbon over a set of scales

entries: Velmarra is usually shown as a dwarven woman with coppery skin and a cloak woven from threads of gold and green. She holds both a ledger and a sickle, and is always shown with her sleeves rolled up.
She is the god of preparation, fairness, and earned abundance. She is not a god of excess, but of "enough" — enough to store, to share, to sustain.
Her shrines double as granaries and communal storehouses. Her clergy help manage local economies, keep winter stores, and ensure no one goes hungry by oversight or greed.
Velmarra rarely speaks through myths. Her truth is in balance — in grain weighed justly, and hands paid fairly.

entries.name: Proverb
entries: Measure twice, give once, and none go hungry.

deity.name: Seris
deity.title: the New Dawn
deity.symbol: A rising sun over broken ground
deity.worshipers: Healers, mourners, exiles, those seeking change

entries: Seris appears as a young elven woman, wrapped in pale robes, hair flowing like morning mist. Sometimes she is faceless, a silhouette of light stepping through a doorway.
She is worshipped in liminal spaces: dawn, spring, the beginning of life or the end of all things. She is called upon by the broken, the grieving, and the hopeful.
No grand temples are built in her name. Instead, candles are lit in her name beside graves, on long journeys, or at the opening of a new path.
Some say she rose from the ashes of a time when all seemed lost — not a god of vengeance or restoration, but of gentle beginnings.

entries.name: Proverb
entries: Even ashes make fertile ground.

deity.name: Myrrash
deity.title: the Howl Between Worlds
deity.symbol: A jagged spiral struck through by a lightning bolt
deity.worshipers: Wild sorcerers, elementalists, prophets of disaster

entries: Myrrash is worshipped by storm-chasers, planar scholars, and those touched by madness. Said to have been born in the moment a bolt of lightning struck an open spellbook during a planar rift, they represent chaotic insight — flashes of brilliance that crack the mind. Their sermons are storms; their temples are found only on mountaintops or at the edge of arcane catastrophes.
They speak in thunderclaps and riddles, their truths always half-buried beneath static and awe. To Myrrash, magic is no mere tool — it is a living storm, and mortals are fools to claim control.

entries.name: Proverb
entries: When the sky speaks, don't ask it to explain.

deity.name: Thalira
deity.title: She of Root and Ruin
deity.symbol: A tangle of thorns wrapped around a jawbone
deity.worshipers: Druidic death cults, feral tribes, Assassins specialising in poisons

entries: Thalira is not nature's beauty — she is its indifference, predation, and wrath. She is worshipped by those who believe the wilderness should not be tamed, but should devour what civilization dares to build. Her forests do not heal; they hunt. Her rot feeds nothing but decay.
Legends speak of her form as a corpse entwined with moss and venomous flowering vines. She teaches that death is not an ending but a feast — one the soil remembers.

entries.name: Proverb
entries: The earth does not mourn you — it consumes you.

entries.name: {@race Human|XPHB|Humans}
entries: The most common race in Myrrane, {@race Human|XPHB|Humans} are found throughout the land.

entries.name: {@race Human (Offworlder)|RUSTY|Offworlder}
entries: {@race Human (Offworlder)|RUSTY|Offworlders} are humans from 'our world'.
